title.narrative: Power Up MesoAmerica

description.narrative: Power Up! is a consortium of women’s rights organisations led by JASS, together with the Coalition of African Lesbians (CAL), a queer, Pan-African, feminist organisation; PEKKA, a national women-headed family empowerment network in Indonesia; and Gender at Work (G@W), an international feminist knowledge network. Power Up! will engage with women human rights defenders (WHRD) and their organisations and networks, particularly those that represent constituencies that have been marginalised in their communities and social movements (LBQ3 women, HIV+ women, sex workers, women workers and rural and indigenous women). Together, we will be building, organising, mobilising and transforming power on three strategic agendas: bodies, voices and resources. Strategic objective: Increase collective influence and impact women have on laws & policies, the public discourse and social attitudes and narratives that cause social descrimination, violence and exclusion, contributing to the full realisation of women’s rights and gender equality.

mailing-address.narrative: 1900 L Street NW Suite 504 Washington DC 20036 United States Tel: +1.202.232.1211 Fax: +1.202.232.4715

sector.narrative: Women’s rights organisations and movements, and government institutions

1. Direct solidarity to participant of Alquimia Leadership School in Honduras facing crisis. 2. JASS Meso participated in a solidarity event tio commemorate victims of the internal armed conflict Guatemala.

JASS Meso cultivated 9 new allies in Mesoamerica (names withheld to ensure safety).

title.narrative: 4.2. Enhanced capacity of WROs to design and implement effective strategies and articulate collective political agendas
4.2.1. # of WROs' (political and technical capacities) strengthened by PU!

comment.narrative: As the indicator measures any new values occurring since the start of the intervention, the baseline value is set at 0. Specific details regarding the situation at the start can be found in the narrative baseline report.
Target is annual, will increase each period

JASS Meso provided organisational political accompainment and strategy support to 2 WROs in Honduras and 2 WROs in Guatemala South Africa (names withheld due to security concerns) working with indigenous women, women human rights defenders particularly those defending land and territory and resisting impunity of corporate and state actors.

title.narrative: 2.2 Women express their views and participate in all decision-making

2.2. VOICES: # of times that WROs (disaggregated by women-led, youth-led or other and formal/informal) succeed in creating space for feminist demands and positions on women’s voice, agency, leadership and representative participation in decision- making processes in public, private and civic sphere, through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or movement building.

comment.narrative: As the indicator measures any new values occurring since the start of the intervention, the baseline value is set at 0. Specific details regarding the situation at the start can be found in the narrative baseline report.
The midline target is set at 50% of the endline target.

JASS Meso supported our partners to create space for their issues, leadership and demands by 1. An art contest that made visible the perspective of women defending land and territories in Honduras. 2. An annual advocacy and communications campaign: Justice for Berta Caceres. 3. Engaging with the new Dutch Ambassador for Central America.

title.narrative: 4.1 Increased leadership capacity and organising skills of women to bring about change in their lives and communities
4.1.1b # women (non-youth) who report increased confidence, political skills and consciousness as a result of PU! interventions

comment.narrative: As the indicator measures any new values occurring since the start of the intervention, the baseline value is set at 0. Specific details regarding the situation at the start can be found in the narrative baseline report.
Target is annual, will increase each period

JASS Meso facilitated feminist movement building workshops and dialogues to build the confidence, political skills and consciouness of women reaching 288 women in Honduras and Guatemala. 1. Training of feminist popular educators from Guatemala and Honduras. 2. Feminist movement building and leadership strengthening workshop with a indigenous women's collective in Guatemala. 3. Dialogue on elections and the role of social movements and challenges for women's and feminist movement's (including exchanges with US activists) 4. Alquimia Feminist Leadership School. 5. Art contest for indigenous women. 6. Virtual launch of "10 reasons to use Cedaw" with indigenous and rural women.

JASS is not reporting disaggregation for 2021, we are adjusting our monitoring system to be able to do this. Young women are a consituency of but they are not the main/only constituency (of JASS or of Power Up!) and these targets should have been for women (non-youth).

title.narrative: 1.1 Women make decisions about their bodies, violence is reduced and safety is improved
1.1. BODIES: # of laws, policies and strategies blocked, adopted or improved to eradicate all forms of violence against women in public and private life.

comment.narrative: As the indicator measures any new values occurring since the start of the intervention, the baseline value is set at 0. Specific details regarding the situation at the start can be found in the narrative baseline report.

At the midline, it is expected that 50% of all country targets of this indicator have been reached. For IATI, this indicator will show the 5 year target both for midline and endline as it cannot be predicted in advance which ones will be completed.
